title: 103_hr4897
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on winnings from state lotteries or gambling establishments to withhold payment until a child support arrearage is determined. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act includes procedures for withholding payments from state lotteries or gambling establishments until a child support arrearage is determined. Enforcement agencies can withhold and pay the arrearage amount, and insurance payments can be suspended pending inquiry on child support obligations. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act allows for withholding payments from state lotteries or gambling establishments to determine child support arrearages. Payments can be suspended pending inquiry on child support obligations. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act allows for withholding payments from state lotteries or gambling establishments to determine child support arrearages. Payments can be suspended until an inquiry is made to the State agency regarding any child support owed, and if there is an arrearage, the payment can be withheld and paid to the State agency for distribution. If the State seizes property forfeited by an individual due to a criminal offense, the same rules apply. The State must withhold payments from state lotteries or gambling establishments to determine child support arrearages and pay the withheld amount to the State agency for distribution. If the State seizes property forfeited by an individual due to a criminal conviction, it must hold the property until an inquiry is made to the State agency about any child support arrearage owed. If there is an arrearage, the State can sell the property and use the proceeds to satisfy the claims of other claimants before deducting the amount owed. Any person required to make payment in respect to a decedent shall suspend the payment until an inquiry is made to and a response received from the State agency. Any person making payments for a deceased individual must suspend the payment until confirming with the State agency if the recipient owes child support. If there is an arrearage, the person must withhold and pay the amount to the State agency for distribution. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for State licensing departments to withhold licenses from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants and individuals delinquent in child support payments. State motor vehicle departments are authorized to withhold driver's licenses and vehicle registrations from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants or individuals delinquent in child support payments until certain conditions are met. This includes obtaining consent from the individual owed support, a State prosecutor, or a court, or completing an expedited inquiry and review while granting a 60-day temporary license. Additionally, licenses may not be issued or renewed for noncustodial parents with outstanding failure to appear warrants, capias, or bench warrants. State motor vehicle departments have the authority to withhold driver's licenses and vehicle registrations from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants. This includes suspending licenses for individuals with failure to appear warrants, capias, or bench warrants related to child support proceedings. Individuals with outstanding child support warrants may have their driver's licenses or vehicle registrations suspended by state motor vehicle departments. A temporary license or registration may be granted pending compliance with the order or removal of the warrant. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)), as amended, allows for the seizure of funds in a bank account to pay child support arrears through an administrative process, with notice and an opportunity for the account holder to be heard. State law allows for the seizure of funds from a bank account to pay child support arrears through an administrative process, with notice and an opportunity for the account holder to challenge the seizure. If the account holder fails to successfully challenge the seizure, the institution may be required to pay the arrearage amount or the amount on deposit in the account to the entity with the right to collect the arrearage. SEC. 5 amends the Social Security Act to require courts to report child support obligations to credit bureaus. SEC. 6 addresses the liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to make each parent liable for the financial support of their child if the individual is unable to provide such support.
